SubTopics: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.
Content: The owner of a restaurant buys sets of tables and chairs. She buys 6 chairs for each table.
Which equation shows the relationship between t, the number of tables, and c, the number of chairs?

SubTopics: Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: Lucy traced each face of a three-dimensional shape. The faces she traced are shown.
problems/NMG6M/media/2a.jpg
Which three-dimensional shape did Lucy trace?

SubTopics: Recognize a statistical question as one that anticipates variability in the data related to the question and accounts for it in the answers.
Content: Mr. Brown asked Susan to write a statistical question. This is the question Susan wrote.
:box:How many children does Mr. Brown have?
Did Susan write a statistical question?

A.Choice: Yes, because the answer is a number.

B.Choice: No, because the question is written for only one person to answer.

C.Choice: Yes, because there will be variability in the data collected from this question.

D.Choice: No, because there will be no variability in the data collected from this question.

SubTopics: Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.
Content: Jerry is thinking of two rational numbers, r and s, such that r is located to the right of s on a number line. Jerry made these claims about r and s:

:ibox:• Claim 1: r > s

• Claim 2: |r| > |s|
Which statement BEST describes Jerry's claims?

A.Choice: Only Claim 1 is true for all rational numbers.

B.Choice: Only Claim 2 is true for all rational numbers.

C.Choice: Both Claim 1 and Claim 2 are true for all rational numbers.

D.Choice: Neither Claim 1 nor Claim 2 is true for all rational numbers.

SubTopics: Write, read, and evaluate expressions in which letters stand for numbers.
Write expressions that record operations with numbers and with letters standing for numbers.
Content: Ben has d dollars. Sally has 3 dollars less than Ben.
Which expression represents the amount of money that Sally has?

SubTopics: Display numerical data in plots on a number line, including dot plots, histograms, and box plots.
Content: The number of customer calls received by a call center is shown in this table.
problems/NMG6M/media/6a.jpg
Which graph BEST represents the data in the table?

SubTopics: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.
Content: The table shows the relationship between the time in hours and the distance in miles that a train is traveling.
problems/NMG6M/media/7a.jpg
Based on the table, which equation represents the relationship between the distance, d, and time, t?

SubTopics: Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions when solving a real-world or mathematical problem; understand that a variable can represent an unknown number, or, depending on the purpose at hand, any number in a specified set.
Content: The table shows the prices of some camping gear Jan is buying.
problems/NMG6M/media/8a.jpg
:ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS FOUR PARTS.
Jan buys a sleeping bag and some rope from a 100-foot roll. Write an expression, using a variable (f), to model his total cost. Explain what the variable (f) represents.
There are 100 hand warmers available at the store. Write an expression, using a different variable (h), to model the cost of buying some hand warmers. Explain what this variable (h) represents.
Describe the possible values for each of the variables you used.
Are there any possible values for one variable that are not possible for the other variable? Use words or numbers to explain your answer.

SubTopics: Understand a rational number as a point on the number line. Extend number line diagrams and coordinate axes familiar from previous grades to represent points on the line and in the plane with negative number coordinates.
Find and position integers and other rational numbers on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram; find and position pairs of integers and other rational numbers on a coordinate plane.
Content: Vertex P of triangle MNP is located 2 units directly below vertex N on this coordinate plane.
problems/NMG6M/media/9a.jpg
What are the coordinates of vertex P?

SubTopics: Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.
Content: The perimeter of a rectangle is represented by this expression:
Which expression also represents the perimeter of the rectangle?

SubTopics: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths by packing it with unit cubes of the appropriate unit fraction edge lengths, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths of the prism. Apply the formulas V = l w h and V = b h to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: This right rectangular prism is packed with cubes.
problems/NMG6M/media/11a.jpg
Each cube has a side length of 1/10 meter.
Which expression can be used to find the volume, in cubic meters, of the prism?

SubTopics: Recognize that a measure of center for a numerical data set summarizes all of its values with a single number, while a measure of variation describes how its values vary with a single number.
Content: This list shows data values increasing in order.
Two data values are missing.
Which measures can be determined from the data without the missing numbers?

SubTopics: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context.
Describing the nature of the attribute under investigation, including how it was measured and its units of measurement.
Content: Rashaun surveyed 17 students to determine how often they ate cafeteria food for lunch during the last two weeks. He made this line plot to show the results.
problems/NMG6M/media/13a.jpg
Which would be the BEST label for Rashaun to use on the number line?

D.Choice: Number of Minutes in Lunch Line

SubTopics: Understand that positive and negative numbers are used together to describe quantities having opposite directions or values (e.g., temperature above/below zero, elevation above/below sea level, credits/debits, positive/negative electric charge); use positive and negative numbers to represent quantities in real-world contexts, explaining the meaning of 0 in each situation.
Content: An elevator travels above the ground to different floors in a building. It also travels below the ground to different floors of a parking garage. The bottom of the elevator starts at ground level.
A vertical number line will be used to show the locations, in feet above and feet below ground level, to which the elevator travels. The number line ranges from 150 to –60.
:ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS FOUR PARTS.
What does the number 0 represent on the number line?
What do the numbers 60 and –60 represent on the number line? Explain how you know.

Reese parked her car in the parking garage 30 feet below ground level. She takes the elevator up to a location 30 feet above ground level. Reese thinks that her car is farther from ground level than she is since her car is below the ground.
Is Reese's thinking correct? Explain how you know.
The bottom of the elevator is now 45 feet from ground level. Gary thinks one number can be plotted on the number line to show this distance. Stephanie thinks two numbers can be plotted.
Who is correct, Gary or Stephanie? Explain how you know. In your explanation, include the number or numbers that show this distance.

SubTopics: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.
Solve unit rate problems including those involving unit pricing and constant speed.
Content: Jasmine is painting her bedroom walls. The total area that needs to be painted is 480 square feet. Jasmine was able to paint 320 square feet in 4 hours.
How much longer will it take Jasmine to finish painting if she continues to paint at that same rate?

SubTopics: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context.

Giving quantitative measures of center (median and/or mean) and variability (interquartile range and/or mean absolute deviation), as well as describing any overall pattern and any striking deviations from the overall pattern with reference to the context in which the data were gathered.
Content: Vivian's basketball team scored these numbers of points in the first five games of the season.
Her team scored 27 points in the sixth game and 35 points in the seventh game.
Which measure is affected by including these two scores with the scores of the first five games?

SubTopics: Find the greatest common factor of two whole numbers less than or equal to 100 and the least common multiple of two whole numbers less than or equal to 12. Use the distributive property to express a sum of two whole numbers 1–100 with a common factor as a multiple of a sum of two whole numbers with no common factor.
Content: Which expression shows 48 + 34 as the product of one factor AND the sum of two whole numbers with no common factors other than 1?

SubTopics: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Content: Isabella has 7/8 cup of barbecue sauce. She separates it into 1/4-cup portions.
How many portions of sauce does Isabella have?

SubTopics: Fluently add, subtract, multiply, and divide multi-digit decimals using the standard algorithm for each operation.
Content: Which expressions have a sum of 6.12? Select the TWO expressions.

SubTopics: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Content: Which problem could be solved by dividing 2/3 by 1/6?

A.Choice: Lillie cuts 2/3 of a pie into pieces. Each piece is 1/6 of the total pie. How many pieces of pie does Lillie have?

B.Choice: Tucker cuts 2/3 of a pizza into 6 slices. All the slices are the same size. What fraction of the whole pizza is each slice?

C.Choice: Ethan has 2/3 of a granola bar. He gives 1/6 of the bar to his brother. How much of the granola bar does Ethan still have?

D.Choice: Kaylinn has 2/3 quart of milk. She pours 1/6 of the milk into her cat's dish. What fraction of the milk does Kaylinn still have?

SubTopics: Write an inequality of the form x > c or x < c to represent a constraint or condition in a real-world or mathematical problem. Recognize that inequalities of the form x > c or x < c have infinitely many solutions; represent solutions of such inequalities on number line diagrams.
Content: The highest point in New Mexico is Wheeler Peak at an altitude of 13,161 feet. Which statement can be used to describe a, the altitude, in feet, of any other location in New Mexico?

SubTopics: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.
Use ratio reasoning to convert measurement units; manipulate and transform units appropriately when multiplying or dividing quantities.
Content: A school orders 720 calendars for a fundraiser. The total weight of the calendars is 390 pounds.
What is the approximate unit weight in ounces per calendar?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by graphing points in all four quadrants of the coordinate plane. Include use of coordinates and absolute value to find distances between points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate.
Content: The locations of Charlie's and Luke's houses are plotted on the grid below.
problems/NMG6M/media/23a.jpg
Which expression can be used to find the distance, in units, between Charlie's house and Luke's house?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.
Content: A piece of wood with a length of 6 1/2 feet is cut into two smaller pieces. One of the smaller pieces has a length of 2 1/4 feet.
Which equation can be used to find x, the length, in feet, of the second smaller piece of wood?

SubTopics: Understand a rational number as a point on the number line. Extend number line diagrams and coordinate axes familiar from previous grades to represent points on the line and in the plane with negative number coordinates.

Recognize opposite signs of numbers as indicating locations on opposite sides of 0 on the number line; recognize that the opposite of the opposite of a number is the number itself, e.g., –(–3) = 3, and that 0 is its own opposite.
Content: Points F, G, H, and I are plotted on this number line.
problems/NMG6M/media/25a.jpg
Which point represents –1.2 on the number line?

SubTopics: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context.
Relating the choice of measures of center and variability to the shape of the data distribution and the context in which the data were gathered.
Content: Miranda makes this line plot to show the noon temperatures, in degrees Fahrenheit, during the past two weeks.
problems/NMG6M/media/26a.jpg
:ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
What is the median of the data? Show your work or explain how you know.
Which measure of center, the mean or the median, best represents the data in the line plot? Use the shape of the data distribution to explain how you know.

SubTopics: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context.
Reporting the number of observations.
Content: The dot plot shows the number of push-ups some students did during the push-up challenge at a school.
problems/NMG6M/media/27a.jpg
Based on the dot plot, which statement is true?

A.Choice: Seven students did more than 18 push-ups.

B.Choice: Half the students did more than 15 push-ups.

C.Choice: Thirty students participated in the push-up challenge.

D.Choice: Half the students did between 14 and 16 push-ups.

SubTopics: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.

Make tables of equivalent ratios relating quantities with whole-number measurements, find missing values in the tables, and plot the pairs of values on the coordinate plane. Use tables to compare ratios.
Content: A manager at a store sells bags of red apples and bags of green apples. These tables show the numbers of each type of apple in different numbers of bags.
problems/NMG6M/media/28a.jpg
problems/NMG6M/media/28b.jpg
Which statement BEST describes the ratio of red apples per bag to the ratio of green apples per bag?

A.Choice: The ratios are the same because the greatest number of each type of apple is 72.

B.Choice: The ratios cannot be compared because the numbers of bags and the numbers of apples are different.

C.Choice: The ratio of red apples per bag is less than the ratio of green apples per bag because 24/3 is less than 18/2.

D.Choice: The ratio of red apples per bag is greater than the ratio of green apples per bag because 24 is greater than 18.

SubTopics: Understand the concept of a unit rate a/b associated with a ratio a:b with b ≠ 0, and use rate language in the context of a ratio relationship.
Content: Which equation shows the unit rate, r, in miles per hour, that Diego rode his bicycle?

SubTopics: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.
Solve unit rate problems including those involving unit pricing and constant speed.
Content: If Diego rides at the same average rate, how many miles will he ride in 2.5 hours?

SubTopics: Find the area of right triangles, other triangles, special quadrilaterals, and polygons by composing into rectangles or decomposing into triangles and other shapes; apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: This hexagon has six sides that are each approximately 2.3 units in length.
problems/NMG6M/media/31a.jpg
Which calculation shows the approximate area, in square units, of this hexagon?

SubTopics: Understand the concept of a ratio and use ratio language to describe a ratio relationship between two quantities.
Content: A 15-ounce mixture of water and juice contains 3 ounces of water.
What is the ratio of water to juice?

SubTopics: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.
Content: Mr. Nelson wants to compare costs of the different brands of fertilizer. In one of his comparisons, he determines this ratio for each brand.
problems/NMG6M/media/33a.jpg
What will Mr. Nelson's ratio determine?

SubTopics: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.
Content: Mr. Nelson wants to buy the brand of fertilizer that will provide the greatest amount of nitrogen per square foot of coverage area. Considering that one bag of each brand covers the same area, he chooses Brand A because it has the highest percentage of nitrogen. Did Mr. Nelson choose the brand that will provide the greatest amount of nitrogen per square foot?

A.Choice: Yes, he was correct to choose the brand with the highest percentage of nitrogen.

B.Choice: No, he should have chosen Brand B because it has the lesser weight of the two brands with the lowest percentage of nitrogen.

C.Choice: No, he should have chosen Brand C because it has the greatest value of (size of bag)(percent nitrogen).

D.Choice: No, he should have chosen Brand D because it has the greatest value of (size of bag)/(percent nitrogen)

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.
Content: Cindy noticed that 8/9 of the students in her math class were wearing jeans. A total of 24 students were wearing jeans. 2
Which equation can be used to find s, the total number of students in Cindy's math class?

SubTopics: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths by packing it with unit cubes of the appropriate unit fraction edge lengths, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths of the prism. Apply the formulas V = l w h and V = b h to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: Tyler's fish tank is shaped like a rectangular prism. The dimensions of the fish tank are shown.
problems/NMG6M/media/36a.jpg
Tyler adds water to the tank until the surface of the water is 2 inches below the top of the tank.
What is the volume, in cubic inches, of the water in the tank?

SubTopics: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.
Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
Content: On Jasper's farm, the ratio of cows to sheep is 4 : 1.
There are 120 cows on the farm.
:ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
How many sheep are on the farm?
What percent of the animals on the farm are sheep? Show your work or explain how you know.

SubTopics: Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: Akeem describes the net of a triangular prism in this way:
:ibox:“The net of a triangular prism has two square bases that are the same size and shape, and it has three triangular faces that connect the bases.”
Is Akeem's description of the net of a triangular prism correct?

A.Choice: yes, because triangular prisms have two bases and three faces

B.Choice: yes, because triangular prisms have square bases and triangular faces

C.Choice: no, because the net should have one triangular base and three triangular faces that meet at a single point at the top

D.Choice: no, because the net should have two triangular bases that are the same size and shape and three rectangular faces that connect the bases

SubTopics: Identify when two expressions are equivalent (i.e., when the two expressions name the same number regardless of which value is substituted into them).
Content: The shortest side of a triangle is x units long. The remaining two sides of the triangle are both 3 units longer than the shortest side.
Which expressions can be used to show the perimeter, in units, of the triangle? Select the TWO correct expressions.

SubTopics: Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: Rectangular Prism W has dimensions of 6 2/5 inches, 6 inches, and 2 1/2 inches.
Which rectangular prism has a volume equal to the volume of the Rectangular Prism W?
